team, I added two more columns to our board (<https://jira.hyperledger.org/secure/RapidBoard.jspa?rapidView=41>) that should help with getting a clearer picture of the state of things:

*Backlog*: this includes the stuff that have been picked out of the “To Do” list and are considered priorities for the current and next sprints (2-week to each sprint). when you are done with a work item, please pick something from this column to work on next (edited)

*In Review*: when you have a patch submitted for review, please put the corresponding work item in this status

so the lifecycle goes Backlog -> In Progress -> In Review -> Done

if anyone wants to advocate for something to go from “To Do” to “Backlog”, please bring it up here for discussions

all, we are switching to use the following JIRA board for sprint planning purposes: <https://jira.hyperledger.org/secure/RapidBoard.jspa?rapidView=41>

you can disregard the Kanban board that I created earlier (which doesn’t have sprints as per the Kanban process). the new board has two useful views (see the small buttons in the left navigation pane): Backlog and Active Sprints. 

the “Backlog" view shows everything, in either sprint sections or backlog sections. this is considered a “product backlog view”.

the “Active Sprints” shows the current sprint content (sprint 1 at this moment). with 4 columns for the lifecycle phases of a work item from left to right: Backlog -> In Progress -> In Review -> Done. Don’t be confused with the “Backlog” column in this view, they are still planned for the sprint, but acts as a holding area for all works in the current sprint

<@U1KDHJT6H> <@U1KFBBWG1> <@U0Z81GL6S> <@U1L2C9F3R> here’s some update to the top-level node sdk project: <https://github.com/jimthematrix/fabric-sdk-nodejs>

- refactoring the existing code to individual modules (Chain.js, MemberServices.js, CryptoSuite_ECDSA_SHA.js, Peer.js, FileKeyValueStore.js, X509Certificate.js, utils-x509cert.js, Member.js)
- using Promises on APIs instead callback
- removing Typescript and use javascript for class system
- updating unit tests

so far ca-tests.js runs partially successfully. will move on to the peer APIs next.

why we give up typescript?
typescript follow ES6 module, should more standard in future
also typescript better than JavaScript
strong type should better
<@U2E87MX1A|jokepk> has joined the channel

I’m not sure if it’s “better”. It has certain advantages. Though it also has certain disadvantages. It forces us to install additional development packages, introducing confusion on how to work with available javascript packages, and .d.ts files, and a compilation step. A lot of our developers and testers are still confused by the fact that editing the resulting .js file during testing does NOT save your changes as the source files are still actually in .ts. Therefore, modifying your .js files during testing/debugging would lead you to loose your changes. A lot of developers are also still much more familiar with javascript than typescript and that makes adoption/maintenance of the project more difficult.

seems main problem is not familiar with typescript, however it should not be problem after more practice. Also we already have typescript version, revert to javascript seems unnecessary. As Angular 2 final released, typescript maybe popular in future.

see 
<https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/harrisob/F2CRY4F97/nodesdk_quick_start.mp4>

text:
<@U12452RAP> Kai, I added the following explanation to the PR comment in response to your question:

The main reason to remove typescript is to simplify the tool chain in the contributor's development environment. the original motivation for using TypeScript on the node.js SDK project revolved around it's affordance for code structure constructs such as interfaces and classes. while that can be easily achieved with much simpler prototype based javascript techniques as demonstrated in base.js. along with CommonJS modules we can have the equivalence of interfaces and classes rather easily.

for strong typing, I don't think it's a big problem really. I've been on large projects completely based on node.js (one of them made up of 10+ separate microservices projects) and enforcing types using documentation and communication is more than enough. relying on unit tests to enforce types is a much better mechanism.

hope this helps.

<@U12452RAP>  - well we are happy to have you create an SDK in a strongly typed language  :wink:
<@U0PB67X4K> yep, I created a java SDK early by myself. However now there is already a proposal, I think I can help on that.
nodejs 7.0 will release soon, maybe we should change callback to async/await then
I think we should definitely move to nodejs 6.0 as the minimum version we support
and leverage es6 and other new features to simplify things

"move to nodejs 6.0 as the minimum version we support” - I thought about this, it would give us native Promise and class construct. I already use Promise natively, thinking if users complain about the newer node.js version it requires, we can easily paddle back by requiring “bluebird” and we don’t have to change the code. but if we adopt the class support in ES6, then it’s whole different code we’d have to write compared to what I rolled in base.js, with .extend(). if users complain then it’s a lot of work to move off of ES6 class support
guess the question is node.js 6 adoption rate
well I can be convinced of support either v4 or v6 as the minimum requirement as both are the LTS versions with v4 being supported until April 2018 and v6 supported until April 2019
v0.12 support ends 12/31/2016
so no need to continue supporting v0.12
but v6 makes more sense to me as a corporate person as I'd get 2 years of support from the time V1 fabric releases
btw here’s the versions supported by bluemix as a reference point: <http://semver.ng.bluemix.net/node/versions>, latest is 6.6
<@U0Z81GL6S> <@U0MRPSV45> <@U1KFBBWG1>  <@U1L2C9F3R> I think we are good to go wrt Gari’s suggestion of moving to node.js 6+. I’ll start changing the code to use the “class” construct

 Hierarchy 
  - in code defaults
  - files in ./config
       — “default”
       — “development”  unless environment says otherwise
  - environment
  - command line invocation

text: I think it's due to a missing env var that would specify the address (and port?) of the orderer service.  My digging around in the peer golang codebase suggested that the line from fabric/core/committer/noopssinglechain/committer.go  ```orderer := viper.GetString("peer.committer.ledger.orderer")``` is what determines the orderer's address, and as I gather, the string is transformed into CORE_PEER_COMMITTER_LEDGER_ORDERER.
Adding the line ```    - CORE_PEER_COMMITTER_LEDGER_ORDERER=orderer:5005``` seemed to fix this problem.
<@U2X9KDDL7> the direction is correct...

hey all quick question - is there a way to listen to the events stream using `hfc`? Otherwise, is there any way to get the error from an successfully submitted invoke request?
I have a bunch of checks before changing the contract state is permitted and I'd like to get to get why it failed
In v0.6, you can listen to event using eventHub in hfc
you can also generate and listen for chaincode events
chaincode can generate an event per invoke using SetEvent - see eventsender in chaincode examples
to see how to listen using eventhub - see test/unit/event-tests.js
the other option for you if you just want errors is to listen for rejection events(they have the txid that is being rejected)
One other thing to keep in mind, if you enable eventhub (see eventHubConnect), transactions only generate a complete after the transaction has successfully been processed and added to the ledger

Sorry for the wide blast here, but while I was reviewing stuff, thought I should send out a note on things which will make life easier for the maintainers and will help contributions be merged more quickly:

1) Please make sure to reference a JIRA item in your commits - especially for new functionality

2) Let's try to add a little more detail to some of the JIRA entries - one line entries / descriptions don't help us understand what contribution is trying to achieve

3) When people make comments in gerrit, once you address them please mark them as done (by clicking in the comment and hitting done  :slightly_smiling_face:  )

4) You'll notice that we push back a lot on lack of tests - please test locally and use a coverage tool to see where you stand

5) Run linters, go import, etc to reduce CI failures

ok - I thought we had decided to make Node v6 the minimum version since it has the longer lifecycle  (plus it give us access to better features should we need them)
but if people are good with 4.5 then I suppose that's ok
CI currently uses Node v6.7 as well

this is mainly based on this guidance: <https://nodejs.org/en/blog/release/v6.0.0/>:
```
The general rule for deciding which version of Node.js to use is:

Stay on or upgrade to Node.js v4 (currently at v4.4.3) if you need stability and have a complex production environment.
Upgrade to Node.js v6 if you have the ability to upgrade versions quickly and want to play with the latest features as they arrive.
```
so v4 will go into maintenance mode in April 2017, and v6 will become the LTS version at that point
for CI, it might be a good idea to change back to 4.x, and npm back to 2.x

there’s a fairly big change in npm 3 in how it installs dependency’s dependencies, it flattens all dependencies to the top level node_modules, instead of embedding them. i noticed that yesterday when working on patch 7 for 2725
what i ended up doing would work for both npm 2 and 3. but how it was done before in previous patches would not work under npm 2
right - I actually like that  model better.  but if we are going to support Node 4.5, then we should definitely test in CI
